description.narrative:
Additional emergency response support activities for landslide and flood affected families, Samangan#s project overall objective was emergency winterization response and disaster risk reduction, and first aid activities as a continuation for the support to the landslide and flood affected families in Samagan for targeted 371 families of Khoram Sarbagh # Samangan Province. Specific objective
# Support 371 targeted families (2597 individual) to cope against severe climatic conditions through distribution of winterization packages. # Provide appropriate hygiene kits to 371 target families to have the means to practice safe hygiene. # Train and prepare 371 target community members and 45 Community Development Council (CDC) members to be better prepared to minimize disaster risks and equipped to cope with shocks from disaster. Key Impact: # Poor and marginalized families are supported in the cold winter through provision of winterization assistance; # Reduction in post disaster devastation though increased community awareness about hazard; # Disaster risk reduction through hazard identification mechanisms; and # Capacity and equipment in place to provide first assistance at the time of disaster
Activities: 1. Provision of NFI Kits to 371 families: NFI kits were distributed to 371 families at AHEAD#s Samangan office in presence of Director General AHEAD, Humanitarian Manager Oxfam, and representatives from SRRD, MOE, ANDMA, Provincial and District Governor offices. 2. Training 8 CDCs on First Aid:
In addition to distribution of NFI kits for combating with theharsh winter, CDC members (37 males, 8 females (Vice President of CDC), 45 in total) were trained on First Aid to decrease their vulnerability to destruction/human life loss is case of future floods and other natural disasters and on how to provide first aid to the wounded community members. Trainings were conducted at CDC offices for 1 day per CDC. Trainings were completed in 8 days with 4 to 5 CDC members present per training session. Trainings comprised of followings: 1. How to help a person in case of having problem in his breathing system; 2. How to stop bleeding in case of injury; 3. How to Clean small injuries with using chemicals; and 4. How to tight broken leg or hand using special tool for it.
3. Training 8 CDCs on Disaster Risk Reduction:
To Increase their capacity oftaking proper measures to reduce the devastations due to floods and other natural disasters, DRR training was provided to each CDC member (37 males, 8 females (Vice President of CDC), 45 in total). As all CDC members were equipped with maps of their respective villages, the DRR trainings were linked with their respective village maps in order to make the communities understand the concept of hazard mapping and important escape routes of their villages in cases devastating disasters in the future. Trainings were conducted at CDC offices for 1 day per CDC. Trainings were completed in 8 days with 4 to 5 CDC members present per training session. Training for Disaster Risk Reduction comprised of how to take necessary steps to respond appropriately to the Earthquakes, Fire, Flood, Storm, Landslide, Avalanches and Droughts. Steps include selection of emergency escape routes and ways of announcing and alarming the community about directions of movement for safety. In addition, appropriate use of rescue kit items was also part of every training session by the use of learning by doing approach.
4. Distribution of First Aid Kits:
24 first aid kits (3 per CDC) were distributed as part of the project support to vulnerable communities. First Aid Kits were distributed right after completion of training in respective CDC. Items of first aid kit included the followings: Splint to immobilize fractures, Pair of Gloves, Triangular cravat bandage, Headlamp including batteries, Gauze pad, Hemostatic (Blood stopping ) Gauze, Elastic Bandage, Bandage, Anti-septic wipes, Rescue blanket (Sliver/ Golden very light), Plaster, Tourniquets, Wound disinfection, Scissor, Thermometer, Celoxchemostatic Granules (to stop artery bleeding), Chest seal bandage and Special first aid kits box.
5. Distribution of Rescue Kits:
To ensure sustainability of each CDC capacity to provide rescue support to community members in case of potential natural disasters, 8 recue kits (1 per CDC)were distributed to each CDC. Rescue Kits were distributed right after completion of training in respective CDC. Items of rescue kit included the followings:
Flashlight or miner's Lamp for head, Batteries (small), Secondary flashlight or light sticks Army Design, Whistles, Hand-held loudspeaker, Not Pad ( Draft pad ), Pen ( Ball pen Good Quality, Ladder (4metres made of bamboos, Pliers, Hardhats, Crow-bar(Jabal), Wheel-barrow, Hammer, small 500gr (metal) 500, Hammer small 3kg (metal) 3, Plastic Book , Lashing (rope), Shovel, Pick axe, Crescent wrench (Plier), Scissors Medium Size local, Knife (Medium size), Emergency Vests(Apron), Dust Masks, Work gloves (Jeer/Strong cloth), and Stretcher(without wheels and legs).

participating-org.narrative:
AHEAD is a non-governmental, non-political and non-profit organization established in 2008 by Afghan trained professionals those are committed to contribute in improvement of public health, social development, civil society and educational programs. AHEAD is registered under license number 1259 with Ministry of Economy, with the long term Vision of the realization and development of public health, education, community development and a vibrant and vital civil society in Afghanistan where the interest, concerns and dignityof the civilians are taken seriously and more people have access to resources. The Mission of considered as: #contribution to improve the quality of Afghan families# life through provision and distribution of quality health, education services, awareness, community development, civil society development, capacity building and research.
AHEAD continue focusing on actions that directly improveon the lives of the majority poor in the region and inputting into the wider societal challenges as well. The usually expressed need to increase household incomes strikes as the ultimate development goal of the grass root communities with much less interest in putting mechanism to make these incomes sustainable. AHEAD has come a long way in thinking to underpin value for integrated programs which embed the social, political and economic considerations in the emancipation of the grassroots communities from abject poverty. AHEAD has continued to invest in skills, community awareness programs as well advocacy to enable many more community members become informed, analytical of their own contexts and planners of their own development, which in turn can potentially bring in more gains from the available resources of government # as the biggest actor, civil society and the community. This kind of precondition becomes very important for the economic empowerment of the rural people. AHEAD continues its efforts to work further for development and maintains its communication with donor agencies to gain funding sources for further support and achieving its objectives toward achieving the vision.
Since October 2013 ON has been supporting AHEAD in provision of WASH minimum services for 270 IDP families in Balkh province.
Strategic Objectives of AHEAD
1. Health Sector: To improve the quality of health services especially maternal and child health in rural and underserved areas and to increase access of Afghan families to quality health services. 2. Education and Vocational Trainings: To provide education opportunities to orphans by establishing literacy courses in rural areas with special focus on women. 3. Capacity Building: To develop the capacity of health care providers and Afghan professionals by conducting long and short term training courses and workshops. 4. Community Development and Agriculture: To build and develop the capacity of the community through vocational trainings, agriculture, livestock and other development services associations. 5. IDP (Internally Displaced Persons): AHEADis currently implementing an IDP monitoring and profiling for UNHCR in north-east region covering the provinces of Baghlan, Kunduz, Takhar and Badakhshan. Besides AHEAD is implementing WASH project for IDPs in Balkh province. This project is funded by Oxfam Novib. 6. Assessment, Evaluations and Research: To advocate and propose intervention for true Afghanistan-oriented development based on evidence from collaborative (quantitative and qualitative) research. To share findings of researches with relevantgovernmental ministries/departments and other developmental stakeholders in order to establish an evidence for policy development
AHEAD#s currently operating in the following provinces:
Balkh, Baghlan, Kunduz, Takhar, Badakhshan, Samangan, Jowzjan,Faryab, Saripul and Kabul province
